questions.text: Which of the following is true in patients with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease?

choices.text: ADPKD progresses to end-stage renal disease in early adulthood
Calcium oxalate stones are the most common kidney stones
Renal cyst infections are rarely seen
Cardiovascular complications are a major cause of mortality

questions.solution:
Cardiovascular complications are the most common cause of mortality in autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Infections are the second most common cause.

ADPKD is usually clinically silent. Many cases remain asymptomatic until the fifth decade of life and are diagnosed incidentally. PKD-1 mutations cause more severe disease than PKD-2 mutations. The following clinical features may be seen in symptomatic patients:

  • Abdominal mass
  • Back or flank pain 
  • Recurrent UTIs - Renal cyst infections by Gram-negative bacteria are common
  • Nephrolithiasis - most commonly uric acid stones
  • Hematuria
  • Cardiac:
    • Hypertension - early feature  
    • Left ventricular hypertrophy
    • Mitral valve prolapse, valvular insufficiency
  • Extra-renal:
    • Intracranial aneurysms
    • Hepatic cysts

As the cysts grow they compress on the surrounding normal tissue which leads to a progressive reduction in the GFR. Eventually, it leads to end-stage renal disease (ESRD) by the fifth decade of life.

Multicystic renal dysplasia -

  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman developed a sudden severe headache and vomiting. Her neighbor rushed her to the hospital where she was declared dead on arrival. She lived alone and her family history is unknown. An autopsy revealed a subarachnoid hemorrhage and the following findings in her kidneys. Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Mutation of PKD-1 is responsible for 85% of cases
PKD-2 mutation has higher risk of end-stage renal disease than PKD-1
The PKD genes code for the polycystin protein
Cysts are formed only in 5% of the tubules of the kidney

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario with a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) and multiple renal cysts is suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). The PKD-1 mutation has a higher risk of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) than PKD-2.

ADPKD is a disorder which is characterized by progressive bilateral formation of renal cysts. It is caused by the following mutations:

  • PKD1 gene on chromosome 16 (85%) - codes for polycystin-1
  • PKD2 gene on chromosome 4 (15%) - codes for polycystin-2

Polycystins are transmembrane proteins that are present on the primary cilia of the tubular cells. The mutated proteins in ADPKD alter the normal functioning and triggers cell growth and cyst formation.

Though cysts are formed only in 5% of the tubules of the kidney, they compress surrounding renal tissue due to their enormous growth. This results in loss of renal function.

questions.text: In patients with ADPKD, cysts are least likely to be present in which of the following sites?
questions.solution:
In patients with ADPKD, cysts in the lungs are very rare. 

There are very few case reports with lung cysts in ADPKD patients, but the association between ADPKD and lung cysts has not been proved. However, there is a three-fold increase in the incidence of bronchiectasis in ADPKD patients.

The common extrarenal manifestations of ADPKD include: 

  • Hepatic cysts (50-70%) - most common 
  • Seminal vesicle cysts (40%) - can result in infertility
  • Arachnoid membrane cysts (8%) - usually asymptomatic, may increase the risk of subdural hematoma
  • Pancreatic cysts (7-36%)
  • Splenic cysts

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with loss of weight and appetite over the last 3 months. He was diagnosed with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease 15 years ago. A CT abdomen reveals bilateral, multicentric renal masses along with enlarged retroperitoneal lymph nodes. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) with lymph node metastases. The sarcomatoid type of RCC is commonly associated with ADPKD.

Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is a relatively rare complication of ADPKD. There does not seem to be an increased frequency of RCC in these patients compared to the general population. However, when it occurs, it tends to be bilateral, multicentric and of sarcomatoid type.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with persistent headaches over the last 1 month. Her father and paternal uncle suffered from kidney disease and both died in their 50's of a 'brain bleed'. Her blood pressure is 160/110 mm Hg and had also been elevated during a previous visit. Which of the following investigations should be avoided in this patient?

choices.text: Contrast enhanced CT of the abdomen
Non-contrast CT scan of the abdomen
MR angiography of the cerebral vasculature

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). These patients usually have impaired renal function. Hence, contrast-enhanced CT (CECT) would usually be avoided due to the risk of contrast nephrotoxicity.

The following investigations are done in patients with ADPKD:

  • USG abdomen - for screening and diagnosis
  • Non-contrast CT abdomen - more sensitive and picks up cysts of smaller size
  • MR-angiography of brain - pre-symptomatic screening for intracerebral aneurysms

questions.text: How many renal cysts on USG are required to diagnose a 45-year-old patient with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease?

choices.text: At least 2 cysts in each kidney
At least 3 cysts in each kidney
At least 4 cysts in each kidney
Even a single cyst in each kidney

questions.solution:
Between 40-59 years of age, the presence of ≥2 cysts in each kidney is needed to diagnose ADPKD.

This condition is diagnosed based on the USG findings using the Ravine’s criteria:

Age (in years) Imaging findings
15-39  Total of ≥3 cysts, unilateral or bilateral
40-59 ≥2 cysts in each kidney
≥ 60  ≥ 4 cysts in each kidney

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman on dialysis is being planned for a renal transplant with her son as an organ donor. He undergoes a USG scan as part of routine donor evaluation. The following findings are seen. Which of the following will you not recommend for the son?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and USG showing a cystic appearance of the kidney is suggestive of asymptomatic autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). Surgical decompression is not a routine procedure performed in these patients. It may be required only in cases of very large cysts causing persistent pain and infected cysts.

The management includes the following:

  • Analgesics
  • Increased fluid intake 
    • Prevents renal stone formation
    • Reduces growth of cysts by suppressing ADH release
  • ACE inhibitors and ARBs
    • Blood pressure control 
    • Slowing of cyst growth
  • Tolvaptan (V2 receptor antagonist)
    • Reduce pain and slow the decline in renal function
  • Renal transplant
    • Definitive management
    • Pre-transplant nephrectomy may be required in patients with very large polycystic kidneys

questions.text: A 24-year-old G2P1L0 female patient came for an antenatal check-up at 26 weeks gestation. On examination, her abdominal girth was less for gestational age and the fetal parts were easily palpable. Medical records from her previous pregnancy showed that the deceased infant had been positive for a PKHD1 mutation. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the most likely diagnosis of the fetus?

choices.text: It is commonly an asymptomatic and mild disease
In severe cases, it can be diagnosed antenatally on USG
Respiratory insufficiency is uncommon in newborns
It is commonly diagnosed at 5-10 years of age

questions.solution:
A PKHD1 mutation in the deceased infant is suggestive of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD). As the woman has signs of oligohydramnios, it is likely that this fetus also has ARPKD. Severe cases of ARPKD can be diagnosed in-utero with a USG. Prenatal testing can also be done.

ARPKD is a hereditary renal disease of childhood caused by a mutation in the PKHD1 gene on chromosome 6. It codes for fibrocystin/ polyductin (FPC), a membrane protein present in the cells of the cortical and medullary collecting ducts.

Affected fetuses show greatly enlarged kidneys and reduced fetal urine production. This leads to oligohydramnios and pulmonary hypoplasia. About 30% of neonates die soon after birth due to respiratory insufficiency. Most deaths occur < 1 month of life. Others develop chronic kidney disease and hypertension in early childhood.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a typical feature seen in patients with autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Hepatic cysts are not a typical feature of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD). They occur only in rare cases.

ARPKD is usually diagnosed in the neonatal period. These patients commonly have the following findings:

  • Hypertension
  • Chronic renal insufficiency
  • Congenital hepatic fibrosis
    • Biliary dysgenesis with periportal fibrosis is seen
    • Can lead to portal hypertension
  • Caroli’s disease - dilatation of intrahepatic bile ducts

Note: Caroli's disease is also associated with medullary sponge kidney.

questions.text:
Match the following:
 Disease Gene
1.  Medullary cystic kidney disease-1 (MCKD-1)   a. UMOD
2.  Medullary cystic kidney disease-2 (MCKD 2)   b. PKHD1
3.  Adolescent nephronophthisis   c. MUC1
4. Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD)    d. NPHP2
questions.solution:
The gene mutations causing the following cystic disorders are:

  • Medullary cystic kidney disease-1 (MCKD-1) - MUC1
  • Medullary cystic kidney disease-2 (MCKD-2) - UMOD
  • Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) - PKHD1 
  • Adolescent nephronophthisis - NPHP 1-20

Medullary cystic kidney disease (MCKD) is an autosomal dominant disorder. It presents with a late-onset, slowly progressive renal failure. Renal cysts are not common but can be seen occasionally. Medullary cystic kidney diseases are of two types, MCKD1 and MCKD2.

MCKD1 is due to a defect in the mucin 1 (MUC1) gene. The mutated gene codes for a large protein fragment that has a toxic effect on the tubules. It is not associated with elevated uric acid levels and gout.

MCKD2 is due to a defect in the UMOD gene, which codes for the protein uromodulin. It is associated with hyperuricemia and gout.

questions.text: Which of the following is an autosomal recessive renal cystic disease?
questions.solution:
Nephronophthisis is an autosomal recessive renal cystic disease.

It belongs to a category of conditions called ciliopathies. It occurs due to an underlying defect in the primary cilia of the tubular epithelial cells. The cilia play an important role in cell signaling and maintenance of cell growth, proliferation, and secretion.

Other ciliopathies include autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease, and medullary cystic kidney disease.

questions.text: What is the most common inherited cause of  kidney failure in children?
questions.solution:
The most common inherited cause of kidney failure in childhood is nephronophthisis.

Nephronophthisis (NPHP) refers to a group of related, but genetically distinct, autosomal recessive disorders. Mutations are seen in the NPHP genes 1-20. These genes code for nephrocystins which are expressed on the kidney tubules.

NPHP is classified into infantile, juvenile, and adolescent forms. The juvenile form is the most common form. Common features include tubulointerstitial fibrosis, renal cysts, and chronic kidney disease.

questions.text: A child with Joubert syndrome will have which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Joubert’s syndrome is defined by the presence of juvenile nephronophthisis (NPHP) and multiple neurologic findings.

A few examples of multiorgan syndromes associated with nephronophthisis are:

  • Senior-Loken syndrome: NPHP with retinitis pigmentosa
  • Joubert syndrome: NPHP with multiple neurologic findings
  • Bardet-Biedl syndrome: NPHP with truncal obesity, cognitive impairment, retinal dystrophy, and polydactyly

questions.text: The following finding on intravenous pyelography is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a paintbrush or bouquet of flowers appearance on intravenous pyelography (IVP). It occurs in medullary sponge kidney (MSK).

MSK is a sporadic benign condition that is often diagnosed incidentally. It is a developmental defect affecting the formation of collecting tubules and results in cystic dilatation of the medullary and papillary portions of collecting ducts. It is characterized by medullary cysts that are of variable size. It is associated with distal RTA which leads to hypercalciuria. The hypercalciuria leads to a tendency to form calcium oxalate and calcium phosphate stones. The patients can also have recurrent UTIs and hematuria.

CT urography has largely replaced intravenous pyelography as the investigation of choice.
